EAS110Y1-Y-20225.courseDescription: This course is designed to help students build communication skills in the Korean language. Through an integration of listening, speaking, reading and writing, it aims to provide a solid foundation in beginning-level Korean. This course assumes that students do not have any prior knowledge of Korean. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/korean for details. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
EAS110Y1-Y-20225.deliveryInstructions:
Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. 

Students must fill in a mandatory screening form within 48 hours of enrolling on ACORN. Please see: https://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/enrolment-instructions/korean

EAS120Y1-Y-20225.courseDescription: This course is for students with no or a very limited background in Japanese. Students must go through screening process conducted by the Department. See www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/japanese/ for details. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
EAS120Y1-Y-20225.deliveryInstructions: Students must fill in a mandatory screening form within 48 hours of enrolling on ACORN. Students must also attend a mandatory interview with the Japanese Language Coordinator in April. Please see: https://www.eas.utoronto.ca/languages/enrolment-instructions/japanese

EAS235H1-F-20225.courseTitle: Perceptions of China in Japanese Literature
EAS235H1-F-20225.courseDescription: Lectures on Japanese literary negotiations with China, the Chinese and Chineseness, ranging from celebration of shared cultural practices and aestheticization of China to nativist resistance to Chinese cultural hegemony. Required readings are available in English translation, including Tale of Genji, Tale of Middle-Councillor Hamamatsu (medieval romance); Haku Rakuten (No Play); Battles of Coxinga (Kabuki play); Three-Cornered World (by Soseki); and Wild Goose (by Ogai).

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

EAS241H1-S-20225.courseDescription: A historical introduction to Chinese philosophy, covering selected figures and texts from the Warring States period through the Qīng dynasty. Schools of thought covered include Confucianism, Mohism, Daoism, Legalism, “Profound Learning,” Neo-Confucianism, and “Evidential Learning.” Texts and thinkers include the Confucian Analects, Mòzǐ, Mèngzǐ, Xúnzǐ, Dàodéjīng, Zhuāngzǐ, Hán Fēi, Guō Xiàng, Zhū Xī, Wáng Yángmíng, and Dài Zhèn.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

EAS256H1-F-20225.courseDescription: A survey of major works in premodern Chinese literature, including poetry, essays, and short narratives from the pre-Qin through Tang eras (11th century BCE - 10th century CE).

EAS257H1-S-20225.courseDescription: A survey of major works in premodern Chinese literature, including poetry, essays, short narratives and drama from the Song through Qing dynasties (10th - 19th centuries CE).

EAS271H1-F-20225.courseDescription: A survey of the history of Korea from the Tonghak uprising and Sino-Japanese war of 1894-1895, through the colonial period, division, and to the civil war.

EAS273H1-S-20225.courseDescription: This course offers a critical review of the history and historiography of modern Chinese cities. Focusing on the development of specific Chinese cities, the course emphasizes understanding the socio-cultural production of space as well as analytical reading of landscape, urban imagery, and urban writings.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

EAS274H1-F-20225.courseDescription: Through various forms of popular culture in the 20th century, this course explores the cultural contexts and social trajectories of China, Japan and Korea. Forms of popular culture studied include art, visual culture, consumer habits, foodways, advertising, music, and fashion.

EAS296H1-F-20225.courseDescription: A study of Chinese, Japanese or Korean culture, history and/or literature. Content depends on the instructor. When offered, the course will have a subtitle that describes its content.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

EAS314H1-F-20225.courseDescription: Exploration of literature, film, and other cultural production related to the atomic bombing and other nuclear catastrophes from transnational, inter-Asia, and transpacific perspectives. Primarily focuses on, but not necessarily limited to, the cultural texts, intellectual concepts, and social thoughts generated out of the history of Hiroshima and Nagasaki atomic destruction.
EAS314H1-F-20225.deliveryInstructions: Students may also attend this course online (synchronous). If you cannot attend the course synchronously but would like to ask permission to take the course, please email eas.undergrad@utoronto.ca .

EAS340H1-F-20225.courseDescription: This course explores issues of identity, self, and community in a broad exploration of cultural transformation in China.
EAS340H1-F-20225.deliveryInstructions: The lectures will be delivered online at the posted time. Synchronous attendance will be required. Recordings will not be available.

EAS350H1-S-20225.courseDescription: This course analyzes the problem of ideology in relation to the development of capitalism and imperialism in modern Japan. Among the topics analyzed in the course will be: the development of a national ideology in the transition to capitalism, the rise of “ultra-nationalism,” the ideological battles between Communism and fascism, the ideological struggles surrounding the U.S. military occupation of Japan, and the question of national ideology in the postwar period.

EAS357H1-F-20225.courseDescription: This course introduces major issues and events in contemporary Chinese history from the success of the Communist revolution in 1949 to China's postsocialist transitions in the 1980s and early 1990s. Topics include the development and victory of the Chinese Communist revolution, the rule and legacy of Mao Zedong (particularly the Hundred Flowers movement, the Great Leap Forward, and the Cultural Revolution); and economic reform and political repression in the era of Deng Xiaoping.
EAS357H1-F-20225.deliveryInstructions: Students may also attend this course online (synchronous). If you cannot attend the course synchronously but would like to ask permission to take the course, please email eas.undergrad@utoronto.ca .

EAS386H1-F-20225.courseDescription: The course examines the cultural practice of nature in China’s past and present, focusing on literary, artistic, spiritual, ethical, political, and scientific aspects of human-nature relation. Through scholarly works and primary sources, the course inquires into the cultural politics of human-nature entanglements.

EAS394H1-S-20225.courseDescription: This course discusses documentary film and DV culture in contemporary China as forms of cultural, communal, and political practices. We focus on films and videos that seek to address important global issues such as peace, environment, and climate change in cross-media approach and in personal tone. We ask: What new tendencies are there in the films and videos? Where can we trace them back to? What fresh possibilities do they bring forth to our aesthetic and public life?

EAS396H1-S-20225.courseTitle: Special Topics in East Asian Studies
EAS396H1-S-20225.courseDescription: A study of Chinese, Japanese or Korean culture, history and/or literature. Content depends on the instructor. When offered, the course will have a subtitle that describes its content.

EAS496H1-F-20225.courseTitle: Advanced Topics in East Asian Studies
EAS496H1-F-20225.courseDescription: An in-depth study of Chinese, Japanese or Korean culture, history and/or literature. Content depends on the instructor. When offered, the course will have a subtitle that describes its content.
